newsitem.title: USA: US thrift IPOs had strong first day premiums in Q4.
newsitem.headline: US thrift IPOs had strong first day premiums in Q4.

text.p: Initial public offerings of thrift mutual-to-stock conversions had strong opening premiums in the fourth quarter of 1996, with an average rise of about 25.5 percent on their first day of trading, according to a study by SNL Securities.

However for the year, the average first-day "pop" was 12.9 percent, the weakest it has been since 1990, the study said. A "pop" is the jump from where an offering is priced and where it opens on the market.
In 1996 there were 74 thrift conversions that made market debuts compared with 97 in 1995, although the average asset size of the converting thrifts rose to $220.0 million from $181.7 million.
"The beauty of the conversions is that all you need to be able to participate (in the deal) is a deposit account with the thrift," said Chris Smith, SNL Securities' conversion research editory.
"In a normal IPO, you really have to know someone or have a pre-existing relationship with a broker," he said.
